title: Trump's Diabetic Shock
summary: The reality behind Bernie's wailing about the price of insulin.. Bernie Sanders has been registering his outrage about the price of insulin, and the presidential candidate thinks government-run health care is the solution to high drug costs. But almost no one noticed last week a Trump Administration move that could make the diabetes treatment more affordable for more Americans. In any event the insulin story is more about perverse incentives than corporate greed.

title: Cuomo's Power Outage Portent
summary: Heat-wave blackouts are more likely thanks to his war on fossil fuels.. More than 50,000 New Yorkers lost power amid the weekend's heat wave that strained the city's power grid, one week after a transformer fire left 75,000 New Yorkers in the dark for five hours. Governor Andrew Cuomo is flogging the city utility Con Edison, but the blackouts portend the future disruption from his anti-carbon policies.

title: Puerto Rico Protests: Thousands Demand Governor's Resignation
summary: Demonstrators swarm a highway in San Juan. SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico-Tens of thousands of Puerto Ricans swarmed a major highway Monday, the latest in demonstrations demanding the resignation of Gov. Ricardo Rosselló.

title: A Crackdown in Hong Kong?
summary: Meanwhile, Trump praises Xi Jinping for acting 'very responsibly.'. The people of Hong Kong have gone into the streets for seven straight weeks to preserve their liberty from mainland China's encroachment. The demonstrations have largely been peaceful, but on Sunday some violence broke out, and the growing fear is that China and the Hong Kong government will use it as an excuse for a crackdown that could inspire still more violence.

title: Ukraine's Reform Opportunity
summary: The country's comedian president now has the power to get serious.. Voters Sunday gave President Volodymyr Zelensky and his new political party the power to reshape Ukraine's economic and political systems. Now Ukrainians will find out if the newcomers they've gambled on are up to the challenge.

title: How Drug Companies Are Using Your DNA to Make New Medicine
summary: Partnership between Glaxo and 23andMe has produced six potential drug targets but raises ethical questions. Genetic test-kit company 23andMe Inc. has for years used saliva to tell millions of consumers how closely related they are to Neanderthals or whether they are likely to develop diseases like diabetes or Alzheimer's. Now, it's fulfilling a bigger ambition: drug development.

title: Aluminum Suppliers Kick Our Cans
summary: Investigate companies like Alcoa, which kept prices high even after Trump lifted tariffs in May. According to President Trump, tariffs can be "completely avoided if you buy from a non-Tariffed Country, or you buy the product inside the USA (the best idea). That's Zero Tariffs." Unfortunately, this isn't quite true for anyone buying aluminum. Thanks to manipulative business practices that appear to permeate the industry, it doesn't matter if you buy from a tariffed company or an American one-you'll still pay the same high price.

title: Every Cancer Patient Is One in a Billion
summary: The disease's endless variety is reminiscent of Tolstoy's observation about unhappy families.. Cancer physicians for more than a century have followed the simple dictum that more is better-more surgery, more radiation, more chemotherapy and, most recently, more immunotherapy. But how much is enough? Do we escalate doses to the point of lethality, as those engaged in bone-marrow transplantation are forced to do regularly? Is this struggle to eliminate every patient's cancer achievable or even warranted?

summary: Watering hole was just named World's Best Bar at Tales of the Cocktail, the bar industry's annual gathering in New Orleans. summary: Highlighting China's religious persecution is good politics, at home and abroad.. The big news from Washington is that Woodrow Wilson is back. title: The Teachers Union Secession Crisis
summary: An exodus of NEA locals prompts new, restrictive bylaws.. The National Education Association, America's oldest and largest teachers union, faces a revolt from its member unions. In the past five years at least 11 local teachers unions have departed from the NEA and its state affiliates. In response, the NEA recently passed two bylaws to impose roadblocks and crushing penalties on locals seeking to leave the national body.

title: 'Blue-Collar Conservatism' Review: A Law-and-Order Kinda Guy
summary: Philly's Mayor Frank Rizzo, formerly police commissioner, was once photographed in a tuxedo with a billy club tucked into his cummerbund.. 'Two weeks in Philadelphia." That, in the old joke, is second prize; first prize is one week. Of course, the joke is unfair to a great American city, one that has given us the Declaration of Independence, cheese-steaks and Rocky. Philadelphia has also given us raucous politics and civic strife-not least in the 1960s and '70s, when it was beleaguered by racial conflict and economic stagnation. Those decades are at the heart of Timothy Lombardo's "Blue-Collar Conservatism," a title suggesting some relevance to Donald Trump, who is not mentioned until the last three pages.

title: Wood Chips Are Not a Green Power Solution
summary: Biomass worsens air quality. The American Lung Association "strongly opposes the combustion of wood and other biomass sources near schools and institutions with vulnerable populations.". The Biomass Power Association, the industry's lobby group, claims biomass is carbon neutral. Unfortunately, the industry has succeeded in lobbying Congress to declare energy from forest biomass carbon neutral, even though scientists disagree.

title: Answer to Urban Disorder Is To Vote for Political Change
summary: If New Yorkers (and for that matter Californians) want improvements in their crime-infested, sanctuary-state, third-world-like locals, they need to vote Republican.. Writing from New York City, Eugene O'Donnell describes the disastrous conditions in the Big Apple under socialist Mayor Bill de Blasio ("Disorder Rises in de Blasio's New York," op-ed, July 15). Perhaps if this was Mr. de Blasio's first term, readers might care. However, after a disastrous first term, New Yorkers re-elected Mr. de Blasio with 66.5% of the vote. So why should anyone be surprised, especially those of us in equally frightful cities and states being destroyed by progressives? If New Yorkers (and for that matter Californians) want improvements in their crime-infested, sanctuary-state, third-world-like locales, they need to vote Republican.

title: Lee Ufan's Quietly Groundbreaking Five-Decade Career
summary: The artist Lee Ufan has pushed the boundaries of painting and sculpture. Now a flurry of major solo exhibitions honor the man of steel. ON A CHILLY SPRING morning, Lee Ufan is climbing up and around a quarry on the eastern end of Long Island looking for boulders. The site is a village-size pit of sand and soil, ringed with piles of white stones of varying sizes. Lee, a sculptor, painter and philosopher, has traveled from Manhattan by car. He arrived ready to work, dressed in black jeans, a dark blue jacket and a corduroy shirt of autumnal gold. He is trim and fit-about 5 foot 8 with shaggy silver hair-and he moves quickly through the landscape. He doesn't speak much, mostly keeping to hand gestures. From time to time, he refers to his drawings, sketches of future sculptures. Later, he motions toward a boulder and says, "This is good."

summary: Conservatives' efforts to unseat governor and two state senators are part of a national recall trend. Less than a year after Colorado voters gave the governorship and control of the legislature to Democrats, some Republicans are hoping they have already had enough.

title: Ford's Shrinking China Business Is Hurting Its Global Ambitions
summary: Auto maker's sales in China fell 27% in the first six months of 2019 from the prior-year period. SHANGHAI- Ford Motor Co. 's multibillion-dollar push to expand in China this decade has veered off course, leaving it mired in a sales slump that is weighing on its future in the world's largest auto market.

title: How to Handle the Chaos of a 'Tornado Boss'
summary: Disruptive leaders may like to move fast and break things, but working for them takes an extra level of tact and strategy. Casting oneself as a disruptive leader is in vogue these days, suggesting a bold, take-no-prisoners management style that ignites new trends and crushes competitors.

title: The Tour de France Rediscovers Its Joie de Vivre
summary: After two weeks of racing, six riders are still in contention. Improbably, two of them are French.. Foix, France

title: Debt-Ceiling and Spending Negotiations Split Republicans
summary: Administration officials have indicated that they want to reach an agreement that will win the support of House Republicans. WASHINGTON-Some conservative House Republicans are asking President Trump to reject any agreement to set new spending levels and increase the government's borrowing limit without significant spending cuts, injecting further uncertainty into negotiations toward a deal this week.

title: Robert Morgenthau, Longtime Manhattan District Attorney, Dies at 99
summary: He retired in 2009 after serving 35 years as New York County's top prosecutor. Robert Morgenthau, the longtime Manhattan district attorney known for his pursuit of white-collar crime around the globe, died Sunday at the age of 99.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Medical, Leadership Problems Persisted at U.S. Indian Health Service Hospital, Report Finds
summary: Even after overhaul, government watchdog cites issues at facility on Rosebud Sioux reservation; separate report criticizes handling of opioids at five Indian hospitals. A long-troubled U.S. Indian Health Service hospital continued to be plagued by poor medical care, untrained staff and leadership turnover, despite improvements made there by top agency officials, a government watchdog said.

title: Hong Kong Police Shut Down Seventh Weekend of Protests With Tear Gas
summary: Thousands of protesters gather outside key government buildings, including China's liaison office in the city. HONG KONG-Hong Kong police fired a barrage of tear-gas canisters at thousands of demonstrators late Sunday as public unrest stretched into a seventh weekend.

title: New President's Party Wins Big in Ukraine
summary: The Servant of the People's victory cements the political newcomer's power at a critical juncture for the country's relations with Russia and the West. Ukrainians voted overwhelmingly for the party of their former-comedian president in parliamentary elections on Sunday, cementing the political newcomer's power at a critical juncture for the country's relations with Russia and the West.

title: Heat Wave Sets Records, but Relief Is in Sight
summary: Power outages hit New York amid near-100-degree temperatures; cooler, wetter weather is due Monday. A heat wave that gripped a large section of the U.S. set temperature records over the weekend from the Ohio Valley to the East Coast, but forecasters said cooler, wetter weather was expected to begin arriving Monday.

title: Trump Continues to Target Democratic Lawmakers
summary: Advisers push back on charges of racism as the president issues a new attack on the 'squad'. President Trump on Sunday continued to target four progressive lawmakers known as the "squad," while his senior advisers pushed back against assertions from Democrats that he was racist.

title: Salvadoran Leader Tells Pompeo He Wants to Reduce Immigration to U.S.
summary: On last stop of Latin American trip, secretary of state praises cooperation. SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador-The government of El Salvador is committed to improving conditions there to reduce illegal immigration to the U.S., and Washington is prepared to join with it, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said Sunday.

title: Puerto Rico's Governor Won't Seek Re-Election
summary: Ricardo Rosselló's announcement comes amid demonstrations in San Juan. Amid widespread and growing demands for his resignation, Puerto Rico Gov. Ricardo Rosselló said he would remain in office but wouldn't stand for re-election in 2020 as the U.S. territory prepared for another day of demonstrations against his administration.
